NYC Open Data Week 2021

March 6 - 14, 2021

#OpenDataWeek #opendata

About Us

Welcome to Open Data Week 2021!

Hosts: Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics, BetaNYC and Data Through Design 
When: Saturday, March 6th to Sunday, March 14th 2021
Where: 100+ virtual events plus a few outdoor and/or week-long events in NYC
Tune in: #OpenDataWeek

Open Data Week is a week-long festival of community-driven events organized and produced by the NYC Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics and BetaNYC. Every year, New Yorkers come together all across the boroughs to celebrate New York City’s Open Data Law, which was signed into law on March 7, 2012. Coincidentally, the first weekend of March is also International Open Data Day. Together, we use both dates to anchor NYC’s Open Data Week and increase civic engagement with our municipal open data.

 

 

About NYC Open Data Week 2021: This year, from March 6 - 14, 2021, we are doing things a bit differently. 75+ event organizers are hosting virtual sessions to engage with you about open data, technology and design. We invite you to check out the program (scroll down!!) and RSVP to participate in events all throughout the week, as well as with our friends, Data through Design — who have launched a week-long virtual art exhibition. #opendataweek

* Learn more about the NYC Open Data Week Team of organizers.

* Frequently Asked Questions about NYC Open Data Week

Exploring NYC Open Data with Us (Part 1)
Free
Tuesday, March 9
12:00 pm to 1:00 pm
Queens

Hosted By:

  • Queens College

Description:

Two workshops will be given by CUNY Queens College students who are studying data analytics and data visualization. The audience will learn how to use data visualization and machine learning tools to analyze sets of NYC open data, revealing insights and stories behind such data. See below for details.

Data Visualization Workshop, March 9th, 12:00 pm to 1:00 pm

The goal of this workshop is to teach the audience about data visualization using the NYC open data. The NYC open data is ideal in allowing users to create their own visualization on a variety of topics related to NYC life and learn how raw data can be beautified in visuals. This workshop will not only promote data analytics skills among NYC residents but will also provide them with the skills needed to become judicious consumers of information, able to understand and identify misleading visualization.

Guests:
Ying Zhou, Tech Incubator at Queens College
Habiba Aziz, Sociology Department

Machine Learning Workshop, March 10th, 12:00 pm to 1:00 pm

Machine learning (ML) is the core sub-area of Artificial Intelligence (AI), an area of data analytics that is booming. Using NYC open-source data, this workshop aims to educate NYC residents about the importance and role of ML in learning about New York City.

Guests:
Ying Zhou, Tech Incubator at Queens College

Civic Hacking for Transit Equity
Free
Thursday, March 11
6:00 pm to 8:30 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • co:census
  • Urban Institute

Description:

Join co:census for a Civic Hacking for Transit Equity happy hour event to bring together civic leaders, transit agency staff, public servants, designers, coders and engaged citizens to tackle transit equity challenges in New York City.

Schedule

6:00 - 6:30 pm: Kickoff Talk: A panel discussion hosted by co:census founder, Tiasia O’Brien and Urban Institute Principle Research Associate, Christina Stacy for a conversation about transit equity challenges in NYC.

6:30 - 8:00 pm: Civic Hacking: Each team will discuss and brainstorm ideas to increase transit equity based on problem statements. Teams will then ideate and prototype their solution.

8:00 - 8:30 pm: Presentations & Closing Remarks: Each team will present their idea to a panel of judges and prizes will be awarded to the top team.

Guests:

Michael Lau, co:census

AJ Reycer, co:census

Tiasia O'Brien, Founder, Head of Strategy, co:census

Christina Stacy, Principal Research Associate, Urban Institute

Register
Using FOIA Libraries as a Springboard for Civic Education
Free
Tuesday, March 9
10:00 am to 11:00 am
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • Seton Hall University

Description:

FOIA Libraries are robust resources for government data and information. There are over 240 FOIA Libraries containing FOIA responses (with redactions) and frequently requested federal agency information. This can include datasets from many agencies in many formats. This program will emphasize the breadth of government information, including datasets, available to citizens, high school students, college professors, journalists, and non-profits in these FOIA repositories. More outreach is needed to promote these resources. This program is a collaboration opportunity for technologists, civic educators, non-profits and universities during NYC Open Data Week. Ideally, this collaboration would also include data.gov, the portal for U.S. Government open data.

The goal of this event is to bring together government technologists from the General Services Administration, 18F, the Office of Information and Privacy (US DOJ) and FOIA specialists from federal agencies to discuss outreach with civic educators, non-profits and universities.  An additional goal is to generate goals for civic education about FOIA Libraries and data.gov as valuable research repositories. While we know agency responses to FOIA requests may not be publicly available due to FOIA exemptions and/or redactions, the information present in agency repositories can help civic educators teach about agency history and operations, as well as lead citizens and students to primary documents for research in disciplines ranging from political science, international relations, medicine, environmental science, transportation, and history.

Other attendees will include academic librarians and university professors.

Guests:

Lisa DeLuca, Co-Head, Data Services Group and Social Sciences Librarian, University Libraries, Seton Hall University,

DATA2GO.NYC Scavenger Hunt from Home
Free
Friday, March 12
4:00 pm to 5:00 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • DATA2GO.NYC
  • Measure of America

Description:

Starting on Monday, March 8th, join Measure of America (MOA) for our DATA2GO.NYC Scavenger Hunt from Home! Throughout the week, MOA will be sending out scavenger hunt challenges on our Twitter page to help you better understand your neighborhood and NYC.

Challenges will require you to use DATA2GO.NYC, our free interactive social science data tool. For example, challenges may include tweeting screenshots of data points tagging your local congressperson or a non-profit. You must be following us and using the hashtag #DATA2GO in each submission post on Twitter to qualify. The winner will be selected based on their completion of the most challenges and following the posted guidelines. You must be 18 or older to participate. The deadline to send in your challenge submissions via Twitter is Friday, March 12th at 2:00 PM EST.

The winner will be announced on our winner announcement via Zoom on Friday, March 12th at 4:00 PM EST. The $500 PRIZE will be in the form of a donation to a non-profit of your choice. During the online event, we'll also be joined by Kristen Lewis, Director of MOA, and Laura Laderman, MOA's Manager of Data Analysis and Visualization, who will be showing powerful ways to share and visualize data.

Anyone interested is welcome!

How open data can help in the fight against climate change
Free
Tuesday, March 9
9:00 am to 10:00 am
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • Open Data Charter
  • World Resources Institute

Description:

The Open Data Charter and World Resources Institute have developed an Open Up Guide on Climate Action, a tool that allows to explore key datasets that any government should open while promoting transparency at their climate change policy. We have been able to test-drive it both in Chile and in Uruguay and have now learnings, challenges and lessons to share on this growing topic.

Guests:

Natalia Carfi, Acting Executive Director, Open Data Charter

Jesse Worker, Associate at Environmental Democracy Practice, World Resources Institute

The Role of GenZ in the Online Data Privacy Movement
Free
Saturday, March 13
12:00 pm to 2:00 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • PrivaZy Collective

Description:

The tech privacy conversation thus far has been dominated by highly educated and well-established privacy advocates. Those of us who actually grew up using Internet-connected devices (Gen Zers) aren't listening, can't understand when we do, or aren't perceived as authoritative enough to contribute to the discussion. The goal of this session, therefore, is to bridge the gap between the most engaged users of data-driven technologies, Generation Z, and those who create and regulate tech. How can more Gen Zers participate in tech privacy conversations? How can technologists and other career professionals empower young people to voice their privacy perspectives?

We'll start with personal introductions. Then I'll present the case for why the Internet Generation is underrepresented in tech privacy spaces, and why our perspectives are valuable. We'll have a discussion about the aforementioned questions, and brainstorm concrete actions we can take to address these issues.

Afterwards, we'll create virtual guides in Book Creator (https://bookcreator.com/) based on our discussion. Participants will pull online materials from articles, tweets, videos, and other media related to increasing youth involvement in tech privacy spaces within schools, governments, private companies, and nonprofits. Finally, we'll reflect on best practices and takeaways.

Guest:

Zhamilya Bilyalova, Student, Wellesley College

Data by the People, For the People: Flash Talk & Q&A
Free
Friday, March 12
1:00 pm to 2:00 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • Seam Social Labs
  • co:census

Description:

Tiasia O'Brien, Founder of co:census -powered by Seam Social Labs, shares a personal story about her experience with contextual insights that led to her team’s mantra: data by the people, for the people. In her talk, she explains how qualitative data serves as a tool for empowering the voices of the unheard by accessing deep insights and how this can be powerful for businesses as they explore more inclusive & ethical data.

Our goal: to share 3 key principles aimed at democratizing data, building more inclusive data systems, and structuring data in a more community-driven and collaborative fashion.

Guest:
Tiasia O'Brien, Head of Strategy, Seam Social Labs. Founder, co:census

Data Analysis Using Python: A Beginner’s Guide Featuring NYC Open Data
Free
Saturday, March 6
12:00 pm to 1:30 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • Mark Bauer

Description:

NYC Open Data provides a treasure-trove of information - all publicly available with a click of a button. While having access to data is great, its analysis is often a difficult process for beginners, potentially creating barriers in one's open data journey. Additionally, performing data analysis in a reproducible way is often limited or even discarded altogether.

In this virtual talk, I will discuss my project that includes four notebooks that demonstrate key aspects of data analysis. These sections include:

1. How to read (load) and write (save) data with various formats

2. Data inspection and wrangling

3. Data visualizations

4. Geospatial analysis and creating maps

Note: This is not a workshop, and we won't be coding.

Talk Level:

Beginner

Prerequisites:

- Basics of Python or other programming languages (R, SQL, etc.)

- Knowledge of Data Analysis

- Basics of Jupyter Notebooks

This presentation recommends beginner-level proficiency with Python and is focused on applying Python to data analysis; however, those new to Python are gladly welcome!

Materials:

See GitHub repo: https://github.com/mebauer/data-analysis-using-python

About the Speaker:

Mark Bauer is a Data Analyst at the New York City Office of Management and Budget (OMB). He was awarded the New York City Mayor’s Graduate Scholarship in 2018 to pursue an Advanced Graduate Certificate in Urban Science and Informatics at NYU and holds a BA/MCRP in Urban Planning from Rutgers University. Since attending NYU, he has developed many tutorials in Python that assist beginners with extracting and analyzing data from NYC Open Data. He currently lives in New York City.

Twitter: https://twitter.com/markbauerwater

GitHub: https://github.com/mebauer

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/markebauer/

Showcase
Register
K12 Data Science as a Foundation for Equity
Free
Tuesday, March 9
10:00 am to 11:00 am
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • Brown University
  • NYC Department of Education

Description:

Data Science presents a rare opportunity in K12 education, with profound implications for equity. It’s a skillset that brings economic security, and is an important part of being an informed citizen in a data-rich world. With relevant data available in every discipline, we have a chance to integrate computing, instead of competing for instructional hours.

Successful implementation of Data Science in K12 requires a balance between computing, statistics/visualization, and domain knowledge. If taught as a computing class, we'll get a generation of students who can competently perform a linear regression without knowing if their analysis is valid. A pure-statistics class that is focused on math alone will not prepare students for the computational nature of data science, and a class that ignores the role of domain knowledge will lack the personal relevance and cultural connections necessary to make it relevant to all students and subjects.

This presentation will discuss Bootstrap:Data Science, a free Data Science curriculum that has operated at national scale since 2017. We'll share some of the lessons learned from various implementations in small summer programs all the way to launching a cohort with the New York City DOE, as well as DOs and DONTs that any teacher, administrator, or curriculum designer should keep in mind.

Guests:

Emmanuel Schanzer, Co-Director, Brown University

Susan Ettenheim, Computer Science Teacher, NYC Department of Education

Jose Olivares, Director of Computer Science Academics HS, NYC Department of Education

Register
TASC: Democratizing Data for Community Planning
Free
Thursday, March 11
5:00 pm to 6:00 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • The Municipal Art Society of New York
  • Regional Plan Association

Description:

The Municipal Art Society of New York (MAS) and Regional Plan Association (RPA), two of the New York area’s longest standing planning advocacy not-for-profits, have teamed together to create Technical Advancement and Support of Comprehensive Planning and CEQR Reform (TASC). TASC is an innovative new comprehensive and community planning mapping tool that uses open data to assist elected officials, planning practitioners, and most importantly communities on a wide-range of land use actions that affect future development. In the absence of meaningful community-based or comprehensive planning, TASC allows for data-driven community involvement in the planning process and democratizes the availability, accessibility, and usability of public spatial data and advanced planning tools.

As a comprehensive mapping tool, TASC incorporates an extensive array of planning and social vulnerability factors based on regulatory, real estate, neighborhood conditions and socioeconomic conditions at the city tax lot level, that can be used by communities to better anticipate future development in their neighborhoods. As a community planning tool, TASC provides a forum for engaging in community-based groups for planning educational purposes and to glean input to meet the specific needs of New York neighborhoods.

TASC comes at an opportune time. In addition to aligning with the City Council’s burgeoning comprehensive planning efforts, ongoing public land use review (ULURP) and CEQR reform, and a renewed focus on community-based planning, TASC provides a flexible and adaptable vehicle to address development in post COVID-19 New York. Specifically, TASC prioritizes public health factors and social justice issues as they relate to equitable future development, residential and business displacement, and housing affordability, areas that current CEQR methodologies do not adequately address.

Our session will be presented by MAS’s Director of Advocacy, Spencer Williams. The presentation will show how TASC can be used by communities to create and test out various development scenarios. It will also show how TASC would improve the reliability of CEQR in anticipating future development and creating a more accurate analytical framework for evaluating impacts of major land use decisions on city neighborhoods. TASC will also help inform reliable and transparent mitigation measures. Mr. Williams will also discuss the next steps for TASC as it transitions from a mapping tool to a more refined predictive model.

After the presentation, TASC team members Marcel Negret and Maulin Mehta of RPA and Spencer Williams and Caroline Thompson of MAS will be prepared to field questions.

Guests:
Spencer Williams, Director of Advocacy, The Municipal Art Society of New York

Caroline Thompson, Project Manager for Data & Planning, The Municipal Art Society of New York

Marcel Negret, Senior Planner, Regional Plan Association

Maulin Mehta, Senior Associate, State Programs & Advocacy, Regional Plan Association

Whether it's education, transportation, economic development, housing, parks...just to name a few, your Community Board is shaping the conversation and your neighborhood.

We are looking to connect with Data Enthusiasts, Policymakers, Researchers, and the Civic-Tech community. We will present how we built the tool, share insight from trends and topics in Community Board meetings, and brainstorm how this data can be further used, for civic engagement, local democracy, and community building.

Register
Civic Roam – tour a new research tool for searching civic data and documents
Free
Thursday, March 11
3:30 pm to 5:30 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • Civic Roam

Description:

Civic Roam is a new research tool that makes it easy to search civic data and documents. Come explore data about New York City community boards and more pulled from multiple places (from the open data portal, other civic tech tools, and across multiple PDF documents) all organized in one place.

Civic Roam (civicroam.org) is a tool in development, built on new graph database software (Obsidian and Roam Research) that makes it easy to create personal wiki pages of linked data. Civic Roam harnesses this software, and combines it with standardized naming and aliases to create a public knowledge graph on top of open data. Community boards, organizers, journalists, researchers and others can use Civic Roam to do exploratory research that is not easily done with traditional search engines.

A lot of work needs to be done to make Civic Roam more user friendly for the communities it hopes to serve. This project builds on work from NYC Open Data, Beta NYC, Planning Labs, WeGov, and others. Civic Roam is an early stage experiment trying to figure out how to become a useful tool.

Help us identify what data and features would be useful to include in the future and get trained on how to explore open data using a graph database!

Attendees: check out optional background material here: bit.ly/civicroam-odw

Host: Nathan Storey, Civic Roam, Founder

During this workshop, I'll show you how to build extremely useful apps with Airtable, and how to use other free, widely used technology (Slides and Figma) to create shovel-ready, software specifications that users, developers and decisionmakers can actually understand and collaboratively improve.

These tools can make the whole software development process less intimidating and more accessible, enabling you to get better feedback from your stakeholders. Ultimately that leads to building apps faster, better and cheaper.

This training is best for people who:

* are managing lots of spreadsheets and wish they "all connected"
* are now or want to build apps that organize complex information

Register
Open Data As Part of Social Justice Movement: The case for The Data Library of Context
Free
Friday, March 12
12:00 pm to 1:30 pm
Virtual

Hosted By:

  • Civic Software Foundation

Description:

The open data movement has been hailed as the game-changer of this generation, though it hasn’t lived up to the hype. One of the main reasons is the phenomenon of “open-washing” - having evidence for data-driven decision making with no context around data, and with little to no consideration of its implications and embedded biases. This incompleteness then causes scenarios where open data echos the injustices and power imbalances in society. This has spawned new areas of needed intervention to make data actually complete, useful, fair, and accessible. It has become clear that social justice movements have an agenda here too, especially regarding equity in governance by bringing accountability for the data constituents (those represented in or by the data). Our session introduces context metadata as a solution and a way to acknowledge the constructed nature of data. We then present The Data Library of Context as a real-world example and will facilitate a lively discussion around the topic by having critical perspectives from participants. Bonus: an opportunity to apply for a co-creation program.

    Opening Educational Resources for Law
    Free
    Saturday, March 6
    1:00 pm to 2:30 pm
    Virtual

    Hosted By:

    • Legal Hackers Global
    • Kansas City Legal Hackers
    • New York Legal Hackers

    Description:

    Massive open online courses have gained popularity for making free, open, and unlimited learning possible for anyone interested in a wide range of subjects. Unfortunately, when it comes to legal education, such resources are scarce. Legal texts and case books -- invaluable data sources -- are more often locked behind costly paywalls than not. This is not just a problem for those in the legal profession. In fact, it slows down learning, info exchange, and progress in a field that effects all of us by shaping our infrastructure for justice and policy in our communities. Now, we hope to be a part of building an open culture for law.

    This workshop will start with a short presentation to introduce you to open educational resources (OER) for law and how they are transforming legal education and practice. Then, we’ll move into breakout groups for a prototyping session:

    • Persona. Select a persona in the legal system (e.g., legal aid representative, judge, student, etc.)
    • Prototype. Design a prototype for opening the resources familiar to this archetype (e.g., coursework, legal data, case law, administrative information), with a focus on data collection and maintenance, applications, human-centered design, and advocacy
    • Pilot. Identify ways to test the prototype and/or to build a replicable model to open up the resources in your community and beyond

    By the end of the workshop, participants will gain a better understanding about the basics of OER and will leave with a kit for how to deploy OER, themselves. This can be impactful for not just the legal system, but for society more broadly. Teach and learn from your fellow attendees about civic hacking / the law / advocacy / data / education. Together, we’ll build a viable path to opening more and better resources.

    While we will have an eye towards NYC Open Data, we welcome participants from anywhere and everywhere!

    Gabriella Capone, Co-Organizer, New York Legal Hackers
    Jameson Dempsey, Global Director, Legal Hackers
    Bryan Wilson, Co-Organizer, Kansas City Legal Hackers

    Open Data & Ethics: A Case Study from DataKind & New America’s Future of Land and Housing Program
    Free
    Wednesday March 10
    4:00 pm to 5:00 pm
    Virtual

    Hosted By:

    • DataKind
    • The Rockefeller Foundation
    • New America Future of Land and Housing Program

    Description:

    Open data projects offer freedom and transparency for researchers, data scientists, subject matter experts, and critical stakeholders in the design and execution of social impact projects. However, despite enabling social actors to make more informed decisions and create new forms of social mobilization, there remain a number of ethical considerations that must be taken into account.

    In a recent partnership between DataKind, The Rockefeller Foundation, and New America’s Future of Land and Housing (FLH) program, the team sought to explore - and understand - the state of eviction data in the US, and how local governments and organizations might be best supported to use data to help reduce housing instability. For example: (1) Where can eviction data be accessed, and what are the pathways to improve the quality, quantity, and access of this information? (2) What do these data mean to different stakeholders? And (3) What stories can eviction data can (or cannot) tell? However, we are left asking ourselves: What if these data represented me? What would I want to do with it? What story would I want it to tell? As civic tech tools are developed and designed, we seek to engage in a practical conversation regarding data ethics that centers the human behind the data. More specifically, we seek to explore how technologists and social actors can minimize harm and be more transparent and accountable in our actions.

    In this session, a panel of experts will guide audience members in identifying and interrogating ethical dilemmas in open data, particularly in the case of housing eviction data. The interactive discussion will use the FLH project as a case example and introduce some of the ethical dimensions, which must be considered when executing projects using open data. This event will be useful for anyone interacting with open data - whether they‘re an academic, data scientist, program manager, or leader of an organization.

    Guests:
    Benjamin Kinsella, Technical Project Manager, DataKind

    Emily Yelverton, Data Scientist, DataKind

    Mallory Sheff, Senior Portfolio Manager, DataKind

    Nathan Poland, Innovation Fellow, The Rockefeller Foundation

    Timothy Robustelli, New America Future of Land and Housing Program

    Panel
    Register
    MISSING THEM, an open data journalism project to document New Yorkers who have died due to COVID-19
    Free
    Saturday, March 13
    11:00 am to 12:00 pm
    Virtual

    Hosted By:

    • The CITY

    Description:

    As COVID-19 deaths increased in New York City through March and peaking in April, we started looking for data. We knew what we could see: obituaries in local papers. So we began tracking them — pulling names from Legacy.com as well as collecting names that various unions started to make public. We also were able to get very limited data from the city’s medical examiner and health department. While the coronavirus  impacted all of New York, it hit Black and brown communities in the city particularly hard — as THE CITY reported in early April, Bronx residents were twice as likely to die from the virus as other New Yorkers. The MISSING THEM project has evolved into a living memorial of nearly 2,000 publicly-identified deaths — all vetted with public records, searchable, filterable and grouped by occupation — and nearly 300 obituaries written. In addition to the publicly reported deaths, we launched an extensive crowdsourcing campaign asking folks to share stories of those they lost through text, email, voicemail and a Google form. To date, we’ve heard from more than 500 families and friends who lost someone due to COVID-19. Through our collection and engagement efforts, we slowly built out a relational dataset with details about those who have died, their underlying conditions, their last-known addresses from voter registration data and narrative stories submitted by family members. While the published obituaries in local media are about 70% white, MISSING THEM’s community submissions, fueled by our engagement effort, more closely mirror the city’s reality when it comes to COVID-19 deaths: That virus has impacted the above communities in NYC disproportionately. For MISSING THEM submission, 40% identify as not white and 26% as white. Gender numbers also closely align with reality and not with what is recognized in public obituaries in local media. Since the summer, and at different times, a team of graduate interns and students from the Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY and Columbia University, undergraduates from Boston College and a team of 30 volunteers we trained have worked on the project daily. MISSING THEM is the only programmatically-backed, investigative journalism project focused on those who have died from COVID-19 in the United States. THE CITY held a three-day event in December consisting of online programs that included hundreds of family members of those who have died and social service providers, advocates and community members. Those events will spawn others this spring and summer.

    Guests:
    Derek Kravitz, data journalist, Columbia University's Brown Institute for Media Innovation
    Terry Parris Jr., engagement director, THE CITY nonprofit newsroom
    Anjali Tsui, reporter, editor and project manager, MISSING THEM and Columbia University's Stabile Center for Investigative Journalism
    Will Welch, news applications developer, THE CITY nonprofit newsroom

        Description:

        The quality of a child's education depends upon an arbitrary line. School district borders have power and can be leveraged for equity thanks in large part to school funding data that lays bare the severe disparities between school districts along racial and socioeconomic lines. In this session, we will discuss the importance of visualizing school finance and demographic data in identifying these inequitable geographies.

        Former data analysts at EdBuild (a research org focused on improving school funding inequities, closed in June 2020), Megan and Cecilia were responsible for building tools to open our data to the public and make our equity analyses accessible and reproducible for researchers, journalists, and advocates.         1. First we will review the R packages published for technical users of education data: edbuildr and edbuildmapr. This review will include a walk through of the libraries and examples of use cases with an overview of the process for authoring packages in R.

        2. Second we will present an R Shiny Dashboard, developed for non-technical users of education data to visualize and export tables, maps, and plots.

        NYC Opportunity Digital Data Catalog: Promoting a Culture of Open (Meta)Data
        Free
        Wednesday March 10
        11:00 am to 12:00 pm
        Virtual

        Hosted By:

        • NYC Mayor’s Office for Economic Opportunity

        Description:

        Join the Mayor’s Office for Economic Opportunity (NYC Opportunity) as we host a virtual conversation on tackling the challenge of maintaining clear documentation (the good, the bad and the ugly!) about the data we collect, use and share. We will discuss common barriers to curating metadata and steps we are taking to overcome them, including the development of a custom data catalog.

        Good documentation about data sets, products or the systems that produce them is almost as important as the data asset itself. Too often, when data is available, information about that data such as its origin, quality, meaning or use may be hard to come by. Without adequate documentation, it may take considerable effort to specify the right data suitable to answer the research question or achieve the program objective at hand. Even worse, it may increase the risk of inadvertently drawing the wrong conclusion or promoting misinformation.

        In this presentation, NYC Opportunity will discuss our efforts to build better knowledge about the data we collect and share. This includes the development of a new digital data catalog intended to support these efforts and enjoin others with shared challenges to do the same.

        Our goals for this session are to (1) enumerate the core challenges to building adequate data documentation (2) engage an audience around this issue for collective problem solving and (3) demo the NYC Opportunity Digital Data Catalog. The event is open to data scientists, researchers, analysts, developers, product managers and anyone who shares the frustration of seeking out critical information about the data they work with day to day.

        Guest:
        Vanessa Edwards, Director Data Governance and Policy, Mayor’s Office for Economic Opportunity

        Alicia Mathews, Implementation Manager, Mayor’s Office for Economic Opportunity

        The Great, Socially Distant, Bike Parking Scavenger Hunt
        Free
        Saturday, March 13
        11:00 am to 2:00 pm
        Manhattan

        Hosted By:

        • OpenStreetMap US
        • Transportation Alternatives
        • GeoNYC

        Description:

        NOTE - This is an in-person event. The Zoom link was being used in-case of bad weather.

        The Great, Socially Distant, Bike Parking Scavenger Hunt is an in-person OUTDOOR survey of street-accessible bicycle parking with the goal of updating OpenStreetMap. For this year's Open Data Week, the scavenger hunt will kick off in Manhattan.

        Background:
        In 2009 a user known as "cityracks" imported over 3000 bicycle parking features in the 5 Boroughs to OpenStreetMap. These features were sourced from the NYC Department of Transportation (DOT). Over the past 11 years, the data has been sourced by mobile app developers, private enterprises and NYC government despite not being verified on the ground. The cityrack import has grown stale is long overdue for a refresh

        Bicycle parking shortages have been making headlines lately. The New York Times published a story sharing the frustration of bicyclists that cannot find safe and secure parking options. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/27/nyregion/bike-parking-nyc.html. As more people turn to the bicycle it is important for the Open Data community to have the most up-to-date picture of what exists today. OpenStreetMap allows updates to go live immediately for use in a wide array of services. The quality of the data depends on the size and dedication of the local community.

        Format:
        In the age of COVID19 and restrictions from NYS on group sizes, this event will be remote and in person. The in-person portion of the event will involve walking streets in Manhattan so event attendees must exercise caution.
        Prior to the event date, there will be a brief and virtual introduction to the technology being used in the event. It will be the opportunity for everyone to learn about OpenStreetMap, Field Papers and also get informed about how the scavenger hunt will take place.
        On the day of the scavenger hunt groups will meet at their pre-determined location ready to begin looking for bicycle parking spaces. Attendees should plan to bring a clipboard, several pencils with good erasers and the PDF maps assigned to their group.

        Who should attend
        The scavenger hunt is open all New Yorkers interested in bike data, advocacy and want to learn about conducting field surveys. NYC Government employees from the Mayor's Office and DOT for example are encouraged to attend.

        In addition to registering at the link below, please also visit this link to see the Google Slide deck that is required to attend this event. You must fill out the Google Form at the end of the slide deck to confirm you have looked through the material and are coming on Saturday

        Guest:
        Daniel Solow

        Measuring the Digital Divide in NYC: An Open Data Guide
        Free
        Thursday, March 11
        4:00 pm to 5:30 pm
        Virtual

        Hosted By:

        • Citizens’ Committee for Children of New York

        Description:

        One of the most immediate and wide-ranging effects of COVID-19 has been the urgent need for internet access to pursue daily activities in a safe virtual setting. However, digital life is not available to all New Yorkers: close to 500,000 NYC households lack any type of internet connection (including broadband, dial-up, satellite, and cellular data).

        This event will begin with a data walkthrough from Citizens' Committee for Children (CCC) on the digital divide across NYC's neighborhoods and communities. This presentation will be accompanied by a discussion on how barriers to internet access have impacted New Yorkers during the COVID-19 pandemic - from students in remote learning, to virtual enrollment in safety net programs, telehealth services, and more.

        The second part of the event will invite participants to explore local datasets from Open Data NYC – like NYC Wi-Fi Hotspot Locations, Broadband Adoption and Infrastructure, and others – and discuss how local initiatives and infrastructure can bridge the digital divide. The session will conclude with an optional workshop, instructing participants on how to plot resources using Google My Maps and overlay Open Data NYC datasets alongside CCC’s neighborhood-level data.

        Local advocates, service providers/policymakers, and everyday New Yorkers all encouraged to attend - especially those passionate about improving digital equity in New York City.

        Guest:
        Jack Mullan, Research Associate, Citizens' Committee for Children of New York

        How have New Yorkers been faring since 2020? – A Data Science Approach
        Free
        Saturday, March 13
        3:00 pm to 4:30 pm
        Virtual

        Hosted By:

        • NYU Center for Data Science

        Description:

        From political unrest to the COVID-19 pandemic, we have been living in very eventful times. We will showcase a data story about how the everyday lives of New Yorkers may have changed from 2019 to the present using 311 Call datasets from NYC Open Data and the Consumer Complaints dataset from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

        Consumer complaints offer crucial insight, allowing consumers to describe their experiences in their own words. Yet what they say can be difficult to analyze systematically. Using natural language processing, you’ll see how consumer responses can be analyzed to identify themes, extract relevant information, and detect various patterns.

        An example of a consumer complaint would be the following:

        “To Whom It May Concern : I hope you have been safe during these uncertain times. 

        Im writing because I noticed that my most recent credit report contains a late paymentreported for my Citibank account. When speaking to a Citibank representative, they confirmed that my auto-payment amount was upped from {$30.00} to {$35.00} without my knowledge during the month of XXXX. If I had known that I was delinquentby {$5.00}, I would have immediately corrected this error, but due to Citibank not informing me until it was too late, my credit score has now droppedsignificantly. This is Citibank taking advantage of the current Covid-19 crisis, as previously I have never had my auto-payment upped within the 6 years of having this credit card open. I don't understand how I did not receive any notifications about this in the mail, and their calls have been flagged as spam risk, which is why I did not give my account information to them over the phone. When I tried calling them back to confirm that it was them calling under the spam risk number, their automated service told me that they are experiencing higher than normal call volumes and would hang up on me. I never received any confirmation from them until it was too late.” 

        Our session will detail the data science techniques that we have applied to our structured and unstructured data. We will explain our entire data science workflow from our preliminary exploratory data analysis to the machine learning and deep learning methods used. It is these methods that will allow us to gain insights into how New Yorkers are faring during these turbulent times.

        Please join us for what will be a very engaging session that will resonate with many. Those that are data enthusiasts, interested in applications of government data, or simply find this topic engaging are encouraged to attend. We will have an allotted time for Q&A to engage with our audience.

        Note: This will be a virtual event.

        The Opportunity Project is a technology innovation program within the U.S. Census Bureau that brings together government, technologists, and communities from around the country to create digital tools that address our greatest challenges as a nation. In the 5 years the program has been running, over 135 tools have been created tackling the challenges related to disaster recovery, economic self-sufficiency, workforce, health, education, and more. Companies, universities, nonprofits, and many others have participated in the process and created tools like interactive games, mobile apps, mapping tools, data visualization websites, and others to help communities around the country.

        In this talk, hear from members of The Opportunity Project team discuss how this entirely virtual open innovation program works, and how they tackled environmental challenges last year like air quality, recycling, reducing ocean plastics, affordable housing, geospatial data challenges, and many other topics. Attendees will learn about how TOP is scaling data innovation in the federal government, hear case studies on successful products that have impacted communities around the country, and how community building is one of the core tenets of this program. TOP has also open sourced this process through a digital toolkit that allows people to utilize this process on their own, and will walk through it to help attendees learn how they can run this process on their own and make an impact in their own communities. This talk is particularly relevant for those interested in civic tech, open data, and using technology for good, and for anyone interested in getting involved in The Opportunity Project. There will also be time for audience Q&A. This event is for anyone interested in utilizing open innovation methods in their own communities, informed by data, human centered design, and community building.

        How does your neighborhood think about Real Estate Developments? – A fuller spectrum of community voices via Machine Learning
        Free
        Sunday, March 14
        2:00 pm to 3:00 pm
        Virtual

        Hosted By:

          Description:

          Overview:
          The event showcases a data-driven approach using machine learning to analyze and present data on neighborhood sentiments towards real estate development projects across New York City.

          For government agencies, the real estate profession, and community stakeholders involved in new developments, getting reliable information on neighborhood sentiments toward new projects costs immense human and monetary resources and presents major political and financial risks. We propose a data analytics framework to detect pre-existing community sentiments toward different aspects of new developments by processing data from a variety of City records, 311 complaints, demographic and neighborhood characteristics, and online information (news, op-ed columns, discussions, social media). Most of the public data are available from NYC Open Data platform, and we have to explore other available data that will help enhance our research and better understand the biases of different sets of data. The research will explore the sentiments towards a variety of core issues associated with new development by New York City neighborhoods.

          By mitigating risks associated with the failure for public and private sectors to fully grasp and work with community voices, this project increases the efficiency for community engagement during the early stage of the real estate development process and contributes to a built environment that is better aligned with neighborhood sentiments.

          Format:
          The event will be a combination of a 30min presentation and a 30-45min discussion. We will share the explorations, analyses, and findings regarding the research, and we would want to open up the discussions to the audience and collect their questions, ideas, and thoughts.

          The goals of the event:
          Through this engagement, community members will learn more about their neighborhood’s collective sentiments toward new development. Public and private sectors in real estate developers will learn about how to better detect such concerns and improve the plan and process for developments.

          As for the project team, we look forward to receiving feedback on 1) what other areas of concern that communities and developers need to incorporate before and during the project planning and development process, 2) what other ways there are in which we can collect and analyze non-quantifiable data, and 3) the audience’s thoughts on whether this approach will produce trustworthy results.

          Expect to see:
          We would love to have neighbors, community members, Real Estate developers, city employees, anyone who is interested in new developments and machine learning join our event.

          Betty Difei Chen
          Bowen Deng
          Yuxiang Luo

          Panel
          Register
          Interview Prep Group for Data Professionals
          Free
          Tuesday, March 9
          6:00 pm to 8:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • Share Our Strength

          Description:

          The Interview Prep Group for Data Professionals has been an ongoing, weekly virtual meet up since September 2020. It's a space founded with the aim of bringing job hunters together, preparing for the arduous 'onsite' technical interview to have a place where they can practice answering interview questions live with others.

          I have a background as a professional musician and educator, dedicating a chuck of my life to the study of pedagogy and performance excellence. I believe the technical interview is more like an audition, and notice a huge downfall to these experiences amongst data and tech professionals, namely, that experienced and knowledgeable candidates often fail technical interviews because they don't 'perform' well and aren't able to convey their knowledge and expertise on the spot.

          In this meet up, we work on 3 interview style questions as seen in data science, data engineer, data analyst and business intelligence engineer interviews. Many of the attendees in the meet up can come up with a solution on their own at home, when there is no pressure of time or explaining their solutions out loud, but it is much more challenging when put to the test of speaking your solution. So this meet up provides a space to allow people to formulate their answers in plain English, explaining their algorithms out loud and voicing their thought process.

          This gives attendees the opportunity to get feedback on their 'performance' as well as to refine their solution to these data problems. It also provides a space of community where attendees can meet other who are also going through the job hunt and share experiences.

          I have written a 3-part blog series on my thoughts and background on the technical interview process if you would like to hear more about the motivation for this meet up, here: https://towardsdatascience.com/become-an-expert-at-the-technical-interview-part-i-2f3db6273982

          The format of the meet up typically follows this schedule within 1.5 hours:

          • 15 mins of intro: Introduces everyone, explain goals and aims of meet up
          • 45 mins covering 3 questions:
            • 15 mins per question
            • I introduce the question and ask the group if they have clarifying questions (it's important to practice the art of asking clarifying questions to an interviewer)
            • We then go into breakout rooms of 4-5 people where everyone has a chance to speak and share their thought process of tackling the question
            • We then regroup as a large group and cover the solution to the question and I share resources and takeaways relevant to that question (tips on why the interviewer is asking the question and what they're looking for)
          • 30 mins at the end for open discussion and questions

          For open data week, I might suggest making this a 2 hour session given there will most likely be more people and I can spend some extra time explaining the motivation of the meet up and leaving space for questions and follow ups.

          This meet up is mostly for people preparing for the aforementioned job types, however it's really open to anyone who enjoys problem solving with others and wants to improve their technical communication.

          The job titles listed above typically cover a range of topics, so the questions I ask cover topics from the following list:

          Python & algorithms
          Business & product sense
          Modelling & machine learning
          Probability
          Statistics & Experiment Design
          SQL

          Most questions are sourced from sites such as Interview Query, HackerRank, confeti.ai, aws machine learning practice exam papers, and more.

          The founder of Interview Query, Jay Feng, may be joining me with this event but that is yet to be confirmed.

           

          Guest:

          Leana Critchell, Cloud Architect, Share Our Strength

          Panel
          Register
          Building EquityNYC: The Road to Making New York City’s Equity Data More Accessible
          Free
          Friday, March 12
          3:00 pm to 5:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • NYC Mayor’s Office for Economic Opportunity
          • NYC Mayor’s Office of Operations

          Description:

          Background: The Social Indicators and Equity Report (SIER) is mandated by Executive Order 45: OneNYC Equity Review (EO45). As the implementation of the executive order was scoped, the team began to think outside of the mandate. The 2020 SIER evolved into what is now the EquityNYC Report and website.

          EquityNYC is a digital tool and report that contains both outcome and service level data, disaggregated by race/ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, and income. This data disaggregation allows for agency partners to conduct equity assessments that identify disparities to inform equity-driven policy creation. EquityNYC includes other features such as Equity Strategies—policies and programs that aim to increase equity and reduce gaps in NYC, and Equity Stories—blog-style content submissions to uplift equity-related work behind the scenes at NYC agencies.

          Goals:

          • Tell the story of  how a two and a half-page Executive Order became a small but diverse team with a wide range of skill sets who designed a product with accessibility and a broad audience in mind, and the  process for de-mystifying equity data at every agency
          • Stress the focus and importance of accessibility and user-friendliness
          • Explain why it’s important and how we envision the tool can and will be used

          Format - Demo and Discussion

          1. Summarize the SIER and EO45
          2. Demo EquityNYC
          3. A panel of EquityNYC team members, including several partner agencies who contributed data and are a testament to the community-building/movement-making

          Who Should Attend

          Those who are interested in:

          • Disaggregated data by demographics and/or location
          • Policy-making through data analysis
          • Identifying disparities in outcomes or service delivery
          • Equity in New York City
          • How to build an accessible tool
          • How to build community (around a cause/mission) in government

          NYC Mayor’s Office for Economic Opportunity:
          NYC Mayor’s Office of Operations:

          MTA Data for Web Dev Using Python
          Free
          Saturday, March 13
          12:00 pm to 2:30 pm

          Hosted By:

          Description:

          Learn how to use the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) data to create an interactive web development experience using HTML/CSS, Javascript and Python (Flask and Jinja) to parse and clean the data feed for a visual user experience. This workshop will require an intermediate to advance knowledge of HTML/CSS, Javascript and Python. We strongly suggest preparing your development environment before attending the workshop series. We are supporting operating systems, macOS Big Sur (v 11.0.1) and up and Windows 10 (v 1909 for x64) and will provide technical support prior to the workshop via email at judesire@yahoo.com

          Workshop
          Register
          Creating a Broadband Bill of Rights for NYC
          Free
          Sunday, March 14
          1:00 pm to 3:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • Community Tech NY

          Description:

          What do teachers, students, library workers, open data advocates, design justice visionaries, essential workers, organizers, and those most impacted by New York City’s uneven broadband market want to see in NYC’s internet? The lack of affordable, quality internet service has meant lack of access to education, opportunity, and health care. Right now we have an opportunity to build out of this crisis for long-term transformation.

          During Open Data Week, Community Tech NY invites you to share your vision of a more equitable, holistically healthy digital ecosystem for New York City. In this deliberative session, we will then discuss and weave together a set of principles and demands as a scaffolding for a Bill of Rights that can be used to inform advocacy for local and citywide efforts.

          Community Tech NY has been working directly with New Yorkers since 2016 to build local power to create the digital ecosystems we want and need for our communities. We believe that as a community builds and stewards its own digital ecosystem, it reclaims collective power.

          Guests:
          Claudina Sarahe (cs), Org Design-Transformation Coach and Facilitator, Composites Collective

          Greta Byrum, Community Tech NY

          Erica Kermani, Community Tech NY

          Community Gathering
          Register
          An Open Path Forward: a Technology Roadmap for a Health Data Team
          Free
          Wednesday March 10
          2:00 pm to 4:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene
          • Open Tech Strategies

          Description:

          How can your team benefit from an Open Source strategy to engage the public in your agency's data? A small data team at NYC Health worked with Open Tech Strategies recently to develop that answer into a roadmap that can provide guidance to agencies in approaching open source. Come and hear from the authors and discuss how you might use this document as a starting point for any municipal agency’s use as it makes plans regarding its technology needs. Important aspects that we will discuss include agile (iterative) methods, de-risking with modular contracting, working out a GitHub policy, handling web accessibility, working with users, and simplifying technology for maintainability.

          Guests:

          James Vasile, Partner, Open Tech Strategies;

          Grant Pezeshki, Computer Systems Manager 1, NYC DOHMH

          Data Through Design: Ground Truth Virtual Opening
          Free
          Friday, March 5
          6:00 pm to 9:00 pm
          Brooklyn

          Hosted By:

          • Data Through Design
          • BetaNYC
          • The Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics

          Description:

          Data Through Design is a yearly data art exhibition that features works which creatively analyze, interpret and interrogate data made available in NYC’s Open Data Portal. The theme for this year is Ground Truth: the insight we receive from being ”on the ground,” collecting or confirming data through direct observation, as opposed to abstract estimates, samples, or reports derived from remote locations. These works investigate data’s relationship to physical place and personal experience.

          Data Through Design 2021 artists will provide an overview of their work

          Data Through Design organizers, welcoming remarks

          NYC MODA, welcoming remarks

          BetaNYC, welcoming remarks

          Workshop
          Register
          Introducing NYC’s Open Data
          Free
          Monday, March 8
          4:00 pm to 5:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • BetaNYC

          Description:

          "New York City’s open data portal has over 3,000 data sets. If you’re not an expert, we have a workshop to help you understand the bits from bytes, sorts from filters, and groups from counts.

          This workshop will introduce you to the fundamental terms and processes needed to understand NYC’s open data. Additionally, we will orient you to several nyc open data tools to help inform your decision-making.

          Why should you attend? BetaNYC has designed trainings and tools specifically intended to help the general public and community boards access, analyze, map and use government data to inform neighborhood decision-making. These insights come from a multi-year partnership with the Manhattan Borough President Gale A. Brewer.

          Come ready to learn and dive into data! We hope you can join us and learn about the data you create.

          This year, our Civic Innovation Fellows have trained to become Open Data Ambassadors and will be delivering a training each day during Open Data Week. Join a pair of them for a lively introduction to NYC history and government, our City’s Open Data movement, 311, BoardStat, and the Open Data Platform. Co-created with the Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics, the class is sure to get you up to speed with these important developments in NYC civic life and leave you more engaged than ever."

          Vansh and Avi, BetaNYC's Civic Innovation Fellows

          Portal Demo
          Register
          Empowering insights with open geospatial data
          Free
          Tuesday, March 9
          5:30 pm to 7:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • AidData
          • William & Mary geoLab

          Description:

          During this event, you will learn about innovative sources and applications of open geospatial data on a global scale. Members of William & Mary’s AidData research lab and the geoLab will discuss three sources of data aimed at empowering insights leveraging geospatial information. This event includes a presentation and time for questions and discussion on each of the topics below. No prior experience is needed - just an interest in geospatial data!

          GeoQuery is a free tool that provides open-source geospatial data in a simple and easy-to-use format. GeoQuery saves time and lowers the barrier to working with geospatial data by handling the processing of large-scale geospatial datasets. Our talk will provide an introduction to how GeoQuery works and the 50+ datasets available for the entire world, as well as a demo of how GeoQuery can be used to visualize data and produce meaningful insights into geospatial trends.

          The geoBoundaries team in William & Mary’s geoLab works to collect and maintain one of the world’s largest open-source, free and research-ready databases of political-administrative boundaries. The geoBoundaries dataset currently tracks approximately 300,000 boundaries across 199 entities, including all 195 UN member states, Greenland, Taiwan, Niue, and Kosovo. In this talk, attendees will learn more about how data for GeoBoundaries is collected and made freely available, as well as how GeoBoundaries is being used in numerous applications.

          AidData’s dataset on Chinese Government-financed projects is the first of its kind and covers 4,300 projects worth $350 billion between 2000-2014. This dataset leverages AidData’s unique methodology for tracking underreported financial flows and provides insight into previously unmonitored Chinese activity around the world. This talk will provide details on how AidData uncovers and tracks Chinese financing around the world, as well as innovative research and findings that have been produced using this data.

          Guests:

          Soren Patterson, Communications Associate, AidData

          Katherine Walsh, Program Manager, AidData

          Sydney Fuhrig, geoBoundaries Managing Director, William & Mary geoLab

          Showcase
          Register
          Hear, Before
          Free
          Saturday, March 6
          7:00 am to 5:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • delete studio
          • Cornell Tech
          • Cornell Tech and We Be Imagining

          Description:

          Hear, Before is a distributed, geolocated audio experience to overhear the collective experience of moving around New York. Use your phone to experience a combination of oral histories, poetry, and sound snippets overlayed over the whole of New York City. You are encouraged to contribute audio snippets by recording yourself, music, or the soundscape that surrounds you. By upload* these sounds to the map they become available to others to hear as well; making yourself part of this documented narrative. We hope you’ll experience and help build a historical auditory archive of the city with us.

          *all audio snippets are listened to by human moderators, advertising, harassment, and offensive material will not be published to the map.

          NOTE: Our event is a website. We will be asking participants to upload short audio clips. However, besides the volunteered audio clips, no additional data or personal data is recorded, transmitted or stored.

          Guests:
          Amrit Kwatra, delete studio

          David Goedicke, Cornell Tech

          Ilan Mandel, Cornell Tech

          Showcase
          Register
          Travels through XYZ: Unearthing Historic NYC’s Hidden Metadata
          Free
          Saturday, March 6
          7:00 am to 5:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • NYC Heritage

          Description:

          An exploratory interactive time-travel narrative through select milestones in NYC’s early 400-year history. Utilizing select historical maps that form the basis of choice and exploration, the story unfolds through places, periods, and events with a mission toward gathering key heritage assets from each era. The travels prompt questions over "the journey of data" -- in both quantity and quality -- as it guides the determination of a legacy's significance and value.

          The project represents an ongoing work-in-progress developed on Twine, and hopes to engage and learn with one and all -- among them, historians and urban explorers, teachers and students, data wranglers and wordsmiths, museum curators and creative technologists, game developers and AI/ML enthusiasts.

          Anyone is welcome to access the project at anytime for free by visiting https://nycheritage.neocities.org/. Registration: Not required.

          Guest:
          Annabel Alafriz, NYC Heritage

          Register
          Travels through XYZ: Unearthing Historic NYC’s Hidden Metadata
          Free
          Sunday, March 7

          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • NYC Heritage

          Description:

          An exploratory interactive time-travel narrative through select milestones in NYC’s early 400-year history. Utilizing select historical maps that form the basis of choice and exploration, the story unfolds through places, periods, and events with a mission toward gathering key heritage assets from each era. The travels prompt questions over "the journey of data" -- in both quantity and quality -- as it guides the determination of a legacy's significance and value.

          The project represents an ongoing work-in-progress developed on Twine, and hopes to engage and learn with one and all -- among them, historians and urban explorers, teachers and students, data wranglers and wordsmiths, museum curators and creative technologists, game developers and AI/ML enthusiasts.

          Anyone is welcome to access the project at anytime for free by visiting https://nycheritage.neocities.org/ . Registration: Not required.

          Guest:
          Annabel Alafriz, NYC Heritage

          Data Through Design 2021 Artist Panel
          Free
          Sunday, March 14
          4:30 pm to 6:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • Data Through Design

          Description:

          Statistics and datasets form representations that are shaped by the unique point of view and methods of their creation and are never truly objective. This year’s Ground Truth theme invited artists to step out into their world to examine the relationship between public data and the lived experience. We encouraged artists to ask questions like, how do our observations align, or misalign, with what is presented through abstracted data? Does missing information and gaps in context affect our understanding of reality? Join some of our 2021 DxD artists in conversation with former DxD organizer Stephen Larrick as they discuss their inspiration, process, and inevitable challenges in revealing the human stories behind the data.

          Guests:

          • Stephen Larrick, a 2019 DxD organizer, will moderate
          • Snoweria Zhang, Big Apple Recipes
          • Cindy Stockton Moore, Shadow Tag
          • Ivan Himanen, Noah Garcia, Broadway Boogie Woogie
          • Jason Forrest, NEW YORK ALIVE!
          • Brian Foo, The Subway Above Ground

          • Renée Crowley, Wasted Potential
          • Julia Bloom, Compositions
          • Michael Hsu, Compositions
          • Alec Barrett, Every Row is a Garden

          Panel
          Register
          Power to the Public: Why data is only as good as the people who are working with it
          Free
          Thursday, March 11
          2:00 pm to 3:00 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • New America

          Description:

          Hana Schank and Tara McGuinness spent a year researching and writing a book about using data and technology to solve the hardest public problems. It's filled with examples of real change that's been brought about using data. For instance, one story centers on Amen Ra Mashariki, who is currently the Global Director of the Data Lab at World Resources Institute. At the time, he was Chief Analytics Officer for the City of New York Director of the Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics at the City of New York. When he first started working there he decided to look at the city's 311 data. He was especially interested in seeing what was going on in Bed-Stuy, Brooklyn. He was shocked when the data showed that there was no rat problem. When he grew up, there were a lot of rats. In fact, Mashariki knew from personal experience that it was rat infested. Mashariki called a friend who still lived in the projects and asked what had happened to all of the rats. According to the city’s data, he explained, there were no more rats there. His friend laughed. There were plenty of rats, he assured Mashariki. “Then why doesn’t anyone call 311 to complain?” asked Mashariki. “What’s 311?” his friend replied.

          This shows how important it is to have people who have a vested interest in data involved in the data creation, collection, and analysis -- and that it’s simply not happening as often as it should. 

          During this event our speakers will discuss: 
          - What it is about data analytics that makes it especially important to bring diverse experiences to the table
          - What data team diversity looks like and how to ensure it’s happening
          - What the risks are for data teams that do not incorporate community voices?
          - Data is only one of the tools available to modern problem solvers. How it can be used in conjunction with other tools like user interviews, usability research or piloting to ensure policies and practice are diverse.

          Panel
          Register
          Ethics of Data Archives: Crowdsourcing Hyperlocal NYC Data Workshop
          Free
          Friday, March 12
          2:00 pm to 4:30 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • New America

          Description:

          Come share your crowdsourcing story and hear others!

          Archives hold the public repository for future historical knowledge but they also bring up ethical questions about who does the keeping and what datasets are missing. During the pandemic and social unrest, we each began to track information with attention to our immediate location. Hyperlocal communities formed around a neighborhood, a store, city block, a building, or maybe even a floor in your apartment complex.

          How did you use shared spreadsheets and cloud documents? What did you need to know that was not available elsewhere? What do you want to know about your hyperlocal area and why? How should we archive, preserve, and share this information? We’ll reflect where we might want less data and where we might need more sovereign data.

          This community discussion and workshop will consider the ethics of data archiving with a focus on hyperlocal data. We will start with a brief introduction to data justice and see images from Mimi Onuoha's art piece on the “Library of Missing Datasets," before breaking into small group discussions. We'll also hear about successful examples including: the NYC Neighborhood Food Resource Guides that battles food insecurity and BetaNYC data for shoppers with health vulnerabilities. Then, together we will create a list of new data sets we would like to see and think about how information patterns of our daily lives should be preserved.

          We encourage participants to come to the workshop with a specific story or example of hyperlocal digital information sharing.

          Guests:
          Anne L. Washington Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Data Policy, Applied Statistics, Social Science, and Humanities at New York University’s Steinhardt School.
          Matt Bui, PhD. Provost's Postdoctoral Fellow, New York University. Faculty Fellow, NYU Alliance for Public Interest Technology.
          Jonathan Chin, Interim Chief Technology Officer at NYC Food Policy Center Food. NYU alumnus.

          Educating Future Data Workers about Ethics, Bias
          Free
          Monday, March 8
          2:00 pm to 3:30 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

          • New America

          Description:

          The students and early career data professionals of today are the data curators and experts of tomorrow. It’s important that they have the right tools and knowledge so that their work -- and the associated data -- is as good and impactful as possible.

          • In this discussion our experts will talk about why it's important to bring the topics of data equity, ethics, and access into the educational process -- both in and out of school. We’ll cover:
          • What that looks like in college and for early career employees
          • Why it matters
          • How to mentor tomorrow’s data experts
          • Why a discussion and commitment to data and ethics makes data, analytics better all around.
          • Why getting students and early career data workers to take public interest technology jobs is so important.

          • Meredith Broussard is a data journalism professor at the Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute at New York University.           • Mona Sloane, an adjunct professor at New York University’s Tandon School of Engineering and senior research scientist at the NYU Center for Responsible AI, is a sociologist working on inequality in the context of AI design and policy. She currently serves as co-principal investigator

          Workshop
          Register
          Complaints, Outages, Service Interruptions, Work Orders – Trying to Make Sense of NYCHA Heating Outage Data
          Free
          Wednesday March 10
          7:00 pm to 7:45 pm
          Virtual

          Hosted By:

            Description:

            For many years, NYCHA residents have dealt with persistent heat outages - an issue made even more important during COVID-19 and a particularly snowy and cold winter. In this session, we’ll start with a seemingly simple question: how many people living in NYCHA housing lose access to heat each month?

            In the journey to try to answer that question, we’ll untangle how words like “outage” and “complaint” need to be carefully understood; explore how computer software systems being used behind the scenes impact data that is eventually shared with the public; and attempt to make sense of public data dashboards, comptroller reports, and federal monitor reports. Finally, we will talk about what questions can and can't be answered using NYCHA open data, and how understanding the context of where the data comes from is essential before performing any data analysis.

            Using data to support antiracist policies in schools

              Workshop
              Register
              MozFest: How public code can transform the digital future of cities: a visionary discussion
              Subsidy available
              Thursday, March 11
              1:15 pm to 2:15 pm
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • Mozilla Festival

              Description:

              Why should digital transformation of government be open? How does open source software help power this? What are cities doing to ensure that digitally implemented policies are democratic, transparent, and just? These questions will be discussed in this interactive discussion with Ben Cerveny (President & co-founder, Foundation for Public Code) and Ger Baron (City of Amsterdam’s first Chief Technology Officer). The session explores the potential of public code in revolutionizing digital government, and why collaboration and openness are key in this process. Public code is both, computer source code (e.g. software & algorithms), and public policy executed in a public context, by humans or machines. It is explicitly distinct from regular software because it operates under fundamentally different circumstances and expectations. Ger & Ben will discuss innovative examples from Amsterdam’s digital agenda, and how the Foundation for Public Code can help public organizations collectively develop and maintain software.

              Panel
              Register
              MozFest: How you can influence your government’s technology choices
              Subsidy available
              Thursday, March 11
              3:15 pm to 4:15 pm
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • Mozilla Festival

              Description:

              Calling all civic hackers, govtech nerds and activists! The Foundation for Public Code’s mission is “to enable public-purpose software and policy that is open and collaborative”. In practice, we mostly work with government organizations and technology vendors. However, members of the public often ask how they can encourage and help their governments to use open source. We want to use our visibility in this space for good - we’d love to be able to offer constructive suggestions to private citizens who want to get involved with government technology policy. We believe the MozFest community will know how - we’d love to hear what you’ve tried, what you’re doing now, and what strategies you recommend. Obviously laws and culture vary, but hopefully we’ll hear tactics and stories that inspire us all.

              Workshop
              Register
              MozFest: Election integrity and platform accountability: Global lessons from the 2020 U.S. Elections
              Subsidy available
              Wednesday March 10
              4:30 pm to 5:30 pm
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • Mozilla Festival

              Description:

              The high-profile 2020 U.S. Election invited intense scrutiny on how social media platforms approached disinformation and other election integrity issues. A number of organizations (including Mozilla) investigated platform policies to evaluate what measures were in place, how they were enforced, and how effective they were. What can we learn from these unprecedented interventions by platforms, ranging from labeling to ad bans to de-platforming a head of state? Will this level of attention to election integrity by platforms continue for upcoming elections globally? This session will be an opportunity to hear from researchers who investigated platforms’ policies in the U.S. and to share concerns, ideas, and learnings in order to hold these platforms to account.

              Panel
              Register
              MozFest: Out of My Face!: Using Public Records to Understand Government’s Facial Recognition Use
              Subsidy available
              Wednesday March 10
              12:00 pm to 1:00 pm
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • Mozilla Festival

              Description:

              Facial recognition’s use is growing. There are good odds a database already has your face. Government interest in AI use is expanding throughout policing, public benefits, and its other responsibilities, and grassroots activists are critical to keeping use of this tech in check. Public records can help them do that. We’ll learn how to use freedom of information laws to demystify the what, why, and how of government’s technology. We’ll discuss facial recognition’s uses and abuses, the cities that have banned it and the countries that have made it an everywhere and everyday reality. This workshop will be an opportunity to share experiences, skills, and strategy (definitely no technical know-how needed). By comparing notes and concerns, we’ll leave more excited and prepared to consider what, in an ultra-connected society, transparent and responsible AI use can mean for our local and global communities.
