              Community Gathering
              Register
              MozFest: Algorithms in Government & Procurement
              Subsidy available
              Monday, March 8
              3:15 pm to 4:15 pm
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • Mozilla Festival

              Description:

              Globally, we are a fulcrum on the future of automated decision making (ADS) systems within government. How do we build up frameworks that make algorithmic decisions as accountable as the person who is programming them? How do we ensure that government procurement policies enable transparency? If ADS systems are made by the government, are there greater safeguards than if they are made by private developers? If ADS is made by the government, is it more likely to be open sourced? Scrutinized by academics and professionals? The goal of this session is to socialize existing best practices around ADS procurement. We will highlight that government procurement needs critical reform. We will explore how to push back against bad ADS purchases, and how technologists, advocates, civil servants, and lawyers can work together.

              Reception
              Register
              Introducing NYC’s Open Data
              Free
              Monday, March 8
              10:00 am to 11:00 am
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • BetaNYC

              Description:

              New York City’s open data portal has over 3,000 data sets. If you’re not an expert, we have a workshop to help you understand the bits from bytes, sorts from filters, and groups from counts.

              This workshop will introduce you to the fundamental terms and processes needed to understand NYC’s open data. Additionally, we will orient you to several nyc open data tools to help inform your decision-making.

              Why should you attend? BetaNYC has designed trainings and tools specifically intended to help the general public and community boards access, analyze, map and use government data to inform neighborhood decision-making. These insights come from a multi-year partnership with the Manhattan Borough President Gale A. Brewer.

              Come ready to learn and dive into data! We hope you can join us and learn about the data you create.

              This year, our Civic Innovation Fellows have trained to become Open Data Ambassadors and will be delivering a training each day during Open Data Week. Join a pair of them for a lively introduction to NYC history and government, our City’s Open Data movement, 311, BoardStat, and the Open Data Platform. Co-created with the Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics, the class is sure to get you up to speed with these important developments in NYC civic life and leave you more engaged than ever.

              Introducing NYC’s Open Data
              Free
              Friday, March 12
              10:00 am to 11:00 am
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • BetaNYC

              Description:

              New York City’s open data portal has over 3,000 data sets. If you’re not an expert, we have a workshop to help you understand the bits from bytes, sorts from filters, and groups from counts.

              This workshop will introduce you to the fundamental terms and processes needed to understand NYC’s open data. Additionally, we will orient you to several nyc open data tools to help inform your decision-making.

              Why should you attend? BetaNYC has designed trainings and tools specifically intended to help the general public and community boards access, analyze, map and use government data to inform neighborhood decision-making. These insights come from a multi-year partnership with the Manhattan Borough President Gale A. Brewer.

              Come ready to learn and dive into data! We hope you can join us and learn about the data you create.

Co-created with the Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics, the class is sure to get you up to speed with these important developments in NYC civic life and leave you more engaged than ever.

              ¿Sabías que el portal de Open Data de la ciudad de Nueva York tiene más de 3000 conjuntos de datos?

Nuestro instructor hispanohablante presentará una introducción a la historia y el gobierno de Nueva York, el movimiento de Open Data, 311, BoardStat y la plataforma de Open Data en sus proprios términos.

              ¿Por qué debería asistir?

              BetaNYC ha diseñado entrenamientos [see above] y herramientas destinadas específicamente a ayudar a las Juntas Comunitarias a acceder, analizar, asignar y usar datos del gobierno para informar la toma de decisiones en el vecindario. Estos conocimientos provienen de una asociación de varios años con la presidenta del condado de Manhattan, Gale A. Brewer.

              ¡Venga listo para aprender y sumergirse en los datos!

              Portal Demo
              Register
              Data + Disasters: Harnessing the power of data to strengthen emergency response and recovery
              Free
              Thursday, March 11
              12:00 pm to 1:00 pm
              Virtual

              Hosted By:

              • Beeck Center for Social Impact + Innovation at Georgetown University

              Description:

              Attend this panel to learn more about how governments can use data in critical moments for disaster response and recovery.

              In the last year, we’ve seen emergency responders and governments respond to fires, floods, and public health disasters with every resource they have. But many public decision-makers fail to take advantage of one of their most powerful tools: data.

              Accurate, timely information can drastically improve emergency response, though it can be hard for responders to find the right data at the right time.

              We’ll share:

              • Stories from Hurricane Katrina, Hurricane Sandy, and the California wildfires about how civic data champions were able to fill data gaps on the fly to better serve residents.
              • Lessons from the field about how state and county public health agencies might design better data strategies in the wake of COVID-19.
              • How states are reimagining the crucial role of data in responding to peoples’ needs during the long economic recovery ahead.

              State and local government innovators have proven that insights from good data can fundamentally improve how governments respond to crises. But research on data use for response and recovery from COVID-19 have shown that governments have a long way to go before they’re able to effectively leverage data for good.

              Guests:

              Kevin Parker, Beeck Center for Social Impact + Innovation

              Sarah Schacht, Beeck Center for Social Impact + Innovation

              Katya Abazajian, Beeck Center for Social Impact + Innovation

              Kell Crowley, Beeck Center for Social Impact + Innovation

              Register
              The Subway Above Ground – Listening Session
              Free
              Saturday, March 6
              12:00 pm to 4:30 pm
              Virtual
              No location, but highly encouraged to download the songs and listen to them on the subway, en route to and from the events at Avenue B between 7th and 8th Streets by Tompkins Sq. Park!

              Hosted By:

              • Data Through Design

              Description:

              Listen to Brian Foo’s data sonification piece en route to Shadow Tag and New York Alive! This project generates music based on income data from the census blocks one travels beneath while riding the subway. Inspired by the work of minimalist composer and New York City native Steve Reich, 46 data-driven songs that correspond to 46 MTA subway lines will be available to download and play while you ride underground. The dramatic contrasts embedded in each song provide space to meditate on the dramatic differences in income throughout the city.

              No registration required. Feel free to listen while riding to and from the other DxD events: 12:00pm - 1:00pm and 3:30pm - 4:30pm.

              Guest: Brian Foo, Data Artist, The American Museum of Natural History

              https://www.dxd2021.com/thesubwayabovegroundproject-1

              Register
              DxD 2021: Ground Truth Exhibition
              Free
              Thursday, March 11
              7:00 am to 5:00 pm
              Manhattan

              Hosted By:

              • Data Through Design

              Description:

              The theme for this year’s Data Through Design exhibition is Ground Truth: the insight we receive from being ”on the ground,” collecting or confirming data through direct observation, as opposed to abstract estimates, samples, or reports derived from remote locations.

              At a time of unprecedented upheaval—characterized by the overlapping crises of a global pandemic, a long-overdue reckoning over ongoing social and racial injustice, and climate chaos—we invited artists to examine the relationship between lived, real-world experience and the overlay of data and mediated information used to interpret that experience.

              The pandemic has affected not only the work but also the format of this year’s exhibition, which for the first time is being presented online and outdoors, instead of in a gallery space. This constraint prompts reflection on how art in a time of social distancing can straddle the digital and IRL worlds, and how artworks can stake out and maintain a vital presence in the digital realm.

              Data Through Design is an independent collective which organizes an annual art exhibition featuring works that creatively analyze, interpret and interrogate data made available in NYC’s Open Data Portal.

              DxD Ground Truth Artists:

              Snoweria Zhang - Big Apple Recipes
              Cindy Stockton Moore, Rachel Blake, John Stockton, Hoang Pham, Rachel Wetzel - Shadow Tag

              Ivan Himanen, Noah Garcia - Broadway Boogie Woogie
              Jason Forrest, Jen Ray -NEW YORK ALIVE!
              Brian Foo - The Subway Above Ground
              Jennifer Dalton - Feel My City Breaking & Everybody Shaking
              Renée Crowley - Wasted Potential
              Julia Bloom, Sukanya Aneja, Michael Hsu - Compositions
              Alec Barrett - Every Row is a Garden

              Do you know what you are breathing? The air we breathe changes continually, depending on location, traffic, construction, tree canopy, even cooking with gas, you name it!

              This session’s Lightning Talks by five speakers from Europe, Florida and NYC representing community, academic and innovation organizations who will introduce a range of approaches to collecting and interpreting data obtained through open air quality sensors and other public data sources. Placing sensors, open protocols, activating the most vulnerable people and impacting policy are among the topics of this session.

                  NEW YORK ALIVE!
                  Free
                  Saturday, March 6
                  4:00 pm to 4:30 pm
                  Manhattan
                  Ave. B between 7th and 8th Streets by Tompkins Sq. Park

                  Hosted By:

                  • Data Through Design

                  Description:

                  Date/Time: Saturday March 6th, 1 & 4pm (about 15 - 20 minutes for each performance)

                  Location: Ave. B between 7th and 8th Streets by Tompkins Sq. Park

                  Description: Join artist Jen Ray and data designer Jason Forrest as they present a not-entirely-serious exploration of the urges, needs, and desires of New York City residents - both officially in the data, as well as through informal survey results. Inspired by historic influences such as Otto & Marie Neurath Isotype designs and the Triadic Ballet of the Bauhaus, this performance will be a celebration of the city, echoing the interests that make our shared culture so unique. By incorporating movement, props, pictorial statistics, music, megaphones, and good humor we guarantee you've never seen data presented in this way before!

                  Guests:

                  Jason Forrest, Artist

                  Jen Ray, Artist

                   

                  Outdoor
                  Register
                  Introducing NYC’s Open Data
                  Free
                  Wednesday March 10
                  10:00 am to 10:00 am
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • BetaNYC

                  Description:

                  New York City’s open data portal has over 3,000 data sets. If you’re not an expert, we have a workshop to help you understand the bits from bytes, sorts from filters, and groups from counts.

                  This workshop will introduce you to the fundamental terms and processes needed to understand NYC’s open data. Additionally, we will orient you to several nyc open data tools to help inform your decision-making.

                  Why should you attend? BetaNYC has designed trainings and tools specifically intended to help the general public and community boards access, analyze, map and use government data to inform neighborhood decision-making. These insights come from a multi-year partnership with the Manhattan Borough President Gale A. Brewer.

                  Come ready to learn and dive into data! We hope you can join us and learn about the data you create.

                  This year, our Civic Innovation Fellows have trained to become Open Data Ambassadors and will be delivering a training each day during Open Data Week. Join a pair of them for a lively introduction to NYC history and government, our City’s Open Data movement, 311, BoardStat, and the Open Data Platform. Co-created with the Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics, the class is sure to get you up to speed with these important developments in NYC civic life and leave you more engaged than ever.

                  Hosts:
                  Danielle (ODA 1.0) and Kiona

                  Introducing NYC’s Open Data
                  Free
                  Wednesday March 10
                  6:00 pm to 7:00 pm
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • BetaNYC

                  Description:

                  New York City’s open data portal has over 3,000 data sets. If you’re not an expert, we have a workshop to help you understand the bits from bytes, sorts from filters, and groups from counts.

                  This workshop will introduce you to the fundamental terms and processes needed to understand NYC’s open data. Additionally, we will orient you to several nyc open data tools to help inform your decision-making.

                  Why should you attend? BetaNYC has designed trainings and tools specifically intended to help the general public and community boards access, analyze, map and use government data to inform neighborhood decision-making. These insights come from a multi-year partnership with the Manhattan Borough President Gale A. Brewer.

                  Come ready to learn and dive into data! We hope you can join us and learn about the data you create.

                  This year, our Civic Innovation Fellows have trained to become Open Data Ambassadors and will be delivering a training each day during Open Data Week. Join a pair of them for a lively introduction to NYC history and government, our City’s Open Data movement, 311, BoardStat, and the Open Data Platform. Co-created with the Mayor’s Office of Data Analytics, the class is sure to get you up to speed with these important developments in NYC civic life and leave you more engaged than ever.

                  Portal Demo
                  Register
                  Using Data and Design to Bring Older Adults Online
                  Free
                  Thursday, March 11
                  3:00 pm to 4:00 pm
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • NYC Mayor’s Office of the Chief Technology Officer

                  Description:

                  As part of New York City’s COVID relief efforts, the Mayor’s Office of the Chief Technology Officer (MOCTO) distributed 10,000 internet-connected tablets to low-income older adults over the months of April and May. This program was a broad effort across our office, working with a number of partners, and had many components including user research, service design, data visualization, and digital product design and development.

                  The first part of this talk will be a brief background on the state of connectivity in NYC and the impact of COVID-19, as well as an overview of the program’s service design and delivery. The majority of the talk will focus on how our team used Open Data in our participant identification, distribution, and metrics monitoring. There will be a demo of the digital product created using Open Data; an internal dashboard with tracking metrics and geographic visualizations for monitoring the progress of the distribution against goals.

                  Finally, there will be a few snippets of the delightful stories from our user research with older adults who were tablet recipients, and the ways in which they incorporated their tablets into their everyday lives (Music! Gaming! Cooking!).

                  Guest:
                  Elyse Voegeli, NYC Mayor's Office of the Chief Technology Officer

                  Living with Water: Using Qualitative and Quantitative Data on Flooding to Engage with Communities and Agencies
                  Free
                  Friday, March 12
                  1:00 pm to 1:40 pm
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • NYC Mayor’s Office of the Chief Technology Officer

                  Description:

                  Members of the Mayor’s Office of Resiliency, Mayor’s Office of the CTO, the City University of New York, and New York University will come together to discuss their work on flood monitoring, ranging from programs that rely on resident reporting to sensor-based, real-time monitoring. The panel will touch on the different approaches to data collection, how data is shared, and how to effectively work with and for communities.

                  Community Driven Innovation: Challenges and opportunities of participatory policy design
                  Free
                  Friday, March 12
                  12:00 pm to 1:00 pm
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • NYC Mayor’s Office of the Chief Technology Officer

                  Description:

                  No tech & equity policy should be about tech, is should be about solving people's problems

                  The NYCx Co-Labs was created to identify and address local community challenges through participatory research, tech education and open innovation initiatives.

                  Over the last 5 years, the NYCx Co-Labs has worked with communities in Manhattan and Brooklyn to craft global innovation challenges on Safe and Thriving Nighttime Corridors, Zero Waste in Public Spaces, Accessible Mental Health, and Housing Rights.

                  Join us in a session to discuss:

                  • Strategies on how to collect and structure community feedback.
                  • How agencies can visualize data to inform design decisions.
                  • How to identify opportunities for innovation.

                  Guests:

                  Oscar Jorge Romero Jr, Director of Inclusive Innovation and Strategic Programs, NYC Mayor's Office of the Chief Technology Officer

                  Elaine Hsieh, Former NYCx Co-Labs Fellow, and Columbia Graduate Student, NYC Mayor's Office of the Chief Technology Officer

                  Digitizing forms: creating better data and resident experiences
                  Free
                  Wednesday March 10
                  3:00 pm to 4:00 pm
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • Beeck Center for Social Impact + Innovation at Georgetown University

                  Description:

                  If you’ve ever paid for a parking ticket, applied for a permit, or signed up for housing assistance then you’ve probably filled out a government form. Hundreds of services provided by governments across the United States require forms to connect residents to vital services every single day. The data from these forms helps providers to understand more about who and where services are being provided. Unfortunately a majority of these services are still only available on paper, or as (a sometimes editable) PDF, which can create barriers for residents and consume limited city resources. Come listen to digital forms enthusiasts talk about their work in digitizing services.

                  Guests:

                  Sarah Rodriguez, Beeck Center for Social Impact & Innovation at Georgetown University

                  Honey Dacanay, Executive Director of Benefits Delivery Modernization, Employment and Social Development Canada

                  Joshua Gee, Previous Product Manager of Department of Innovation and Technology Digital Team, City of Boston

                  Mayo Nissen, Design Lab Director at the Mayor's Office of the Chief Technology Officer, City of New York

                  Francis Ho, Operations and Programs Director at Center for Families, Children, and the Court, Judicial Council for California
                  Alison Corn, Attorney Technologist and Legal Designer

                  Panel
                  Register
                  Using Data Analysis and Mapping to Address Hate Crimes
                  Free
                  Thursday, March 11
                  1:00 pm to 2:00 pm
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • NYC Mayor’s Office of the Chief Technology Officer

                  Description:

                  In light of recent anti-API (Asian and Pacific Islander) attacks and hate crimes, we discuss the role of data in combatting hate crimes Citywide.

                  Join Hassan Naveed, Deputy Executive Director of the Office for the Prevention of Hate Crimes at the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice (MOCJ), Abdul Rad, Researcher Manager at MOCJ, and Shanna Crumley, Innovation Advisor at the Mayor's Office of the Chief Technology Officer, as they discuss the use of data to address hate crimes holistically.

                  OPHC found a need for a Citywide overview of hate incidents and areas of need to inform effective policy and community-based strategies. They partnered with the Mayor’s Office of the Chief Technology Officer (MOCTO) and the NYC[x] Innovation Fellows program to identify data tools and processes for data-driven decision-making.

                  In 2019, Mayor de Blasio established the Office for the Prevention of Hate Crimes (OPHC) as part of the Mayor’s Office of Criminal Justice (MOCJ), a hub that coordinates activity across a number of agencies and leads targeted interventions to prevent long-term redress of systemic issues.

                  Guests:

                  Shanna Crumley, NYC Mayor's Office of the CTO

                  Hassan Naveed, Deputy Executive Director of the NYC Mayor's Office for the Prevention of Hate Crimes at the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice

                  Abdul Rad, Research Manager at the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice

                  Community Gathering

                  Making NYC’s COVID-19 Data Accessible to the Disability Community
                  Free
                  Wednesday March 10
                  1:00 pm to 2:30 pm
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • NYC Mayor’s Office for People with Disabilities
                  • NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene

                  Description:

                  Data is increasingly becoming more integrated into the day-to-day lives of New Yorkers and people around the world. From neighborhood statistics to public health data, there is a lot of data to consume. Because data is often displayed in complex data visualizations, it is not always easy to access by people with disabilities.

                  During the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, disability advocates all over the country spoke out about city and state governments failing to provide them access to their local COVID-19 data. In this event, the NYC Mayor’s Office for People with Disabilities and the department of Health and Mental Hygiene will share our story working together to make NYC’s COVID-19 data accessible to disabled New Yorkers.

                  Guests:
                  Walei Sabry – Digital Accessibility Coordinator, the Mayor’s Office for People with Disabilities
                  Matthew Montesano – Data Communication Specialist, Department of Health and Mental Hygiene

                  Panel
                  Register
                  Open Data, Privacy, and NYC’s Identifying Information Law
                  Free
                  Friday, March 12
                  10:00 am to 11:00 am
                  Virtual

                  Hosted By:

                  • Mayor’s Office of Information Privacy

                  Description:

                  How does New York City government encourage transparency and protect New Yorkers’ privacy? The City leverages large amounts of information to offer its services, and New York City's Open Data Law requires the City to make certain data public. At the same time, the City’s Identifying Information Law makes sure it uses and shares identifying information responsibly. Come learn more about how these two laws together help the City share information in a way that encourages public trust. This session will be presented by attorneys from the Mayor’s Office of Information Privacy (MOIP), who will also discuss some of MOIP's other privacy-related work.

                  Guests:
                  Kahini Ranade, Associate General Counsel, Mayor's Office of Information Privacy

                  Howard Chen, Assistant General Counsel, Mayor's Office of Information Privacy
